choices: A conference hall at a big company
1.content: Lucy Wong is about to start one her patented Gain-A-Life seminars. Here, she'll pontificate about platitudes, and hopefully sell a few books. Where has her busy travel schedule brought her today?
1.title: Let's start here

12.content: What kind of school is Lucy speaking at?
12.title: A school assembly

choices: An arrogant boy who thinks he's smarter than Lucy
A rude boy who just hates assemblies
121.content:
Grade schools were an interesting stop for Lucy. Her agent advised against such engagements. They were cash sinkholes. Her book, Dynamic Habits for Dynamic Kids: The Young Gain-A-Life System, was rare, in that it failed to reach the bestseller list. Not because it was poorly received, it was simply harder to market self-help to children than adults. Lucy would be lucky to sell five books today. Her appearance fee would just barely cover her flight and car rental. Elementary school assemblies were simply not profitable.

But there was more to life than money. Better study habits, time management skills, and positive life assessment needed to be instilled in people early. The younger, the better. She was proud of her book, even if it didn't sell well. She knew she could help kids, even if she needed to give away her advice for free. And that is why she spoke at elementary schools.

One small benefit to youth seminars, Lucy could speak in a more casual, relaxed attitude. If she wore a power suit today, kids would only see her as another adult authority, talking down to them. Judging them. Demeaning them. She wanted to have a dialogue with the kids. She wore a pair of slacks, bright yellow tennis shoes, and a t-shirt that said "Success" in a fun script. Today's seminar featured less psychology and statistics, and more stories punctuated with jokes. Humor was the easiest way to capture a child's attention.

After enough speeches, Lucy recognized a distinct pattern. The kids would politely listen, mostly thankful for an assembly and a half hour outside of class. But only 20% were actively hanging on her words, taking in her advice. 79% would try to pay attention, they'd laugh at the jokes, but would drift off and daydream throughout the presentation. Lucy didn't fault them. That's just life as a child. But then there was the final 1%.

That final percent were the troublemakers. Whether they were starved for attention, conceited smart-alecks, vocally rude, or just bad seeds, there was always one boy who tried to derail the assembly. And it was always a boy. Lucy didn't pay them any attention. She was a professional. She soldiered forth, continuing on, letting teachers remove the problematic child.

Today's seminar was no different. Just as always, she delivered her presentation, had a brief Q&A session, and thanked the kids. The teachers would guide the students back to class, go over the major talking points together, and hand out fliers advertising Lucy's website store.

Lucy, meanwhile, would have a one-on-one session with today's problematic student. The Young Gain-A-Life System was tried and tested. And today, Lucy would help a brand new Young GAL graduate.


What kind of boy is Lucy helping today?
121.title: Elementary school

choices: Tyler keeps fixating on the ceiling
Tyler is so bored, he reads the book
1211.content:
The school's guidance counselor was kind enough to loan Lucy her office. Young Tyler Jacobson sat in a chair, arms crossed in defiance, waiting for his punishment. This wasn't the first time his attitude got him in trouble.

"Hello, Tyler," Lucy said, taking the seat opposite him.

"Hi," he said, in an attitude fully reflecting his unhappiness. The other kids were out at recess, and here he was, talking one-on-one with some lady. He just listened to her talk for almost an hour. Now he was forced to listen to her talk even more.

"You didn't like the assembly today, did you?" Lucy asked.

"No," Tyler said, matter of fact. Lucy appreciated the boy's honesty. When she confronted adults in similar manners, they always tried to deny their arrogance or misogyny. They tried to walk back their deeds and words. They tried to lie about what just happened. But children were direct. It saved a lot of time.

"I'm a little upset, Tyler. I came all this way to speak to your school. I tried to be helpful and friendly."

"Yeah, I know."

"It's okay if you didn't like my speech. You don't have to. No one was making you. But there were lots of students in the room who did want to hear me speak. And when you acted out, you were denying them of that."

Tyler tried to find the right words. He considered for a moment trying to fake an apology to get back to class. But he realized Lucy wasn't a teacher. She wasn't staff. She was just some lady who liked to talk. She had no authority over Tyler. She couldn't punish him any more than he already was.

"It's just so stupid," he said. "You're not saying anything important. 'Do your homework, try your hardest, set reasonable goals.' Any dope could figure that out on their own."

Lucy took a moment to collect herself. Tyler was impetuous and rude, but he was a child. She couldn't just recite the rules and tell him he was wrong. She needed him to understand his transgressions on his own terms.

"Tyler, I can tell you are a very smart young man," Lucy said, with a knowing nod.

"Uh-huh," Tyler replied, as though Lucy just told him the sun was hot.

"Being smart is a gift. Whether you were born smart, or had to work hard to learn everything, you possess wisdom. No one else in your grade has a mind like yours."

Tyler nodded along, trying to speed up the platitudes.

Lucy continued. "When you possess wisdom, you can either use it to help others, or let it corrupt you. And I'm sorry, I'm beginning to see you've been corrupted."

"So what? I don't care," Tyler said.

"You've started down a path long before you ever met me, Tyler. You'll continue down that path long after I'm gone. All I'm saying is this: try to consider what type of person you want to become."

Ordinarily, Lucy would offer a handshake or a formal goodbye, but Tyler was being obstinate. He didn't want to be here, he didn't want to listen, and he didn't like Lucy telling him what to do. She had said all she could. She stood up, and left the room.

Recess was still going on for another 10 minutes. Tyler was stuck in the guidance counselor's office for the duration. Maybe even longer. Tyler stared upwards at the ceiling tiles. They were boring, but they had all his attention. He didn't even notice Lucy leaving a copy of her Young Gain-A-Life System book on the table.
1211.title: An arrogant boy

choices: Lucy notices a particular student during the assembly
Lucy notices a particular student after the assembly
123.content:
While she preferred the large audiences that job fairs and large hotel ballrooms allowed, Lucy Wong was no stranger to giving back to the community. Every so often, in between corporate retreats and major panels, she liked to do a few school assemblies, after all, no one needs more help than the children of today, who are the adults of tomorrow.

Although that tomorrow was far closer for the subjects of today's assembly. It was a bright September morning when Lucy Wong stood on the stage of Maple River High School's auditorium, giving her speech to the class of seniors that would graduate in the spring, and be sent off into the world of college and then beyond. The most lost and overwhelmed they'd ever be, and needing more guidance than ever.

At least that was what inspired the principal of Maple River High to invite Lucy to the school in the first place. Give the kids one last kick in the pants to ensure that they'd make something of themselves. Lucy was more than happy to do it, while she didn't charge as much for schools, there was always the chance of some teachers would buy a book.

Lucy enjoyed helping to shape young minds, and looked out on the sea of students, some attentive, some having side-conversations, and some just napping, before she began her speech.

Lucy usually found one student in particular who needed her help more than the others, in this case:
123.title: High school

choices: Lucy gives him a voucher for her online course
1231.content:
Lucy was a skilled public speaker, able to memorize her notes, speak eloquently and concisely, but also able to scan the crowd to scout for any potential "major cases". Those who might need a personal touch. In schools, it was even more important, since Lucy's actions could help completely alter the course of the student's life at just the right moment.

"Not only is it important for you to want to get better, but you need to have the initiative and vision to achieve your goals." Lucy scanned the crowd, noticing one student in particular, sitting close to one of the exits.

Clad in a wrinkled hoodie and a beanie, the shaggy haired senior was doing his best to not take the talk seriously. Which was fairly easy with his bloodshot eyes and the scent of marijuana that Lucy could smell wafting up from him. Lucy had seen his kind before, and she'd gotten through to them in the past. He was talking with his group of friends, to several quiet reprimands from teachers, or just generally checking his phone, and ignoring Lucy. But she'd been doing this long enough to not be offended. Of course, she could single him out during the talk, but she always preferred a direct approach.

After being thanked by the principal, Lucy was preparing to depart the school, taking a stroll in the hallway, after the students had returned to class, pulling her rolling suitcase behind her, the only sound in the hallway coming from the click of her heels across the linoleum floors. Turning a corner, Lucy spotted the young man that she'd seen during the assembly shaking a can of spray paint next to a half-graffitied locker.

Lucy stepped forward, the clicking of her heels causing the young man to jump and turn around, trying desperately to hide the can of paint behind his back.

"Nice speech..." he stammered.

"Thank you..." Lucy started.

"Taylor." the young man replied.

"I noticed you, Taylor. You didn't seem to care much about the assembly." Lucy said.

"And why should I?" Taylor asked. "No offense, but I don't buy into your self-help BS."

"None taken." Lucy said. "Why don't you buy into it?"

"People don't change, if you're gonna be a CEO, you've gotta be born into it, and if you're someone like me, college is a waste of time, anyway. If I'm gonna end up in a crappy, dead-end job anyway, why go into debt?"

"College isn't a waste, trust me. It can open up so many doors."

"Not interested, so you can go peddle your crap somewhere else."

Lucy had heard the arguments before. This was no different.

"Suit yourself. By the way, if you have a passion for art, there are better ways to express it than graffiti."

Taylor dropped the can in surprise.

"Uh... are you gonna tell anyone it was me?"

"I'm just here to peddle my BS, not to rat you out." Lucy winked.

"Thanks."

"But, before I go, I'd like you have this. In case you change your mind." Lucy began to dig through her suitcase, pulling out something.
1231.title: Lucy notices a particular student during the as...

choices: Taylor decides to sit with the jocks
Taylor decides to sit with the geeks
12311.content:
"If anything, it makes a nice paperweight." Lucy winked once more and quickly scribbled something on the inside cover, before handing the hardcover book to Taylor.

"Uh... thanks." Taylor looked down.

"Better get to class." Lucy remarked.

"Right..." Taylor tucked the book into his bag and jogged off as Lucy continued on her way out.

Taylor got to his next class, study hall, and quietly slipped into the back. The benefit of it not being an official class, is that the teacher could give less than rat's ass about tardy students. Taylor had planned on skipping, but after that run-in with Lucy Wong... especially since she knew about the graffiti... it was best not to tempt fate.

Unfortunately, because he hadn't planned on it, he had nothing to do, but twiddle his thumbs.

"Although..." Taylor went into his bag and pulled out Lucy's book, "Seven Steps to a More Highly Effective You! What a load of BS..."

With nothing better to do, Taylor started to flip through the chapters, skimming most of them, until he flipped back to the start, and skipping the author's note, he went straight to Chapter 1.

"Chapter 1..." Taylor read to himself. "If you wish to change, you must surround yourself with the type of people you want to be like, learning to emulate their habits. An aspiring baseball player isn't likely to learn how to to hone his craft if he spends all his time at a skating rink, after all."

"I guess that's not bad advice... makes sense, too." Taylor remarked to himself.

It was even starting to awaken questions within Taylor. What did he want to be like? Or rather, who did he want to be like? Surely his ambition wasn't to be a slacker burnout like all his friends, that just sorta happened to be the crowd he fell in with. He still didn't care about college, but a person has to have goals, right?

After study hall, it was time for lunch, and Taylor walked into the lunchroom. Usually he sat with his friends, but for some reason, maybe inspired by the book, he decided to pick a new spot. Where does Taylor sit?
12311.title: Lucy hands him her book

choices: Taylor lends the book to Sophia
Taylor keeps the book... for now
123111.content:
Spotting the table of jocks, which included members of all the school's various sports-related teams, of all genders, although funnily enough, both genders had segregated themselves into separate groups, Taylor took a deep breath and walked over. He'd never really been a sports person, but they seemed to know where they were going, and Taylor needed direction. If anything, it'd be a learning experience.

Taylor sat down at the table, and turned to the group of his peers, several members of the football and baseball teams, discussing whatever local sports game had recently aired on TV, and their rivals' chances of beating them at their next games. Nobody really noticed him, but on the other hand, no one rejected him from the table. It was a good start. Feeling a tad inadequate, Taylor unconsciously puffed out his chest, but just couldn't compare. Taylor remembered another excerpt from the chapter.

"But most important of all, you must be true to yourself. Don't try to attain a goal of being someone so unlike yourself, that you lose what makes you special." a boring platitude, but another logical observation.

Taylor would never be like the jocks, he could tell from simple comparison. They were strong, and Taylor was gangly, this entire exercise had been a waste of time. Taylor started to gather his bag to stand up, when he was tapped on the shoulder. He turned to see a beautiful girl, who he recognized from some of his classes, standing there.

"Is anyone sitting there?" she pointed to the empty space next to Taylor.

"Uh... no." Taylor replied. Girls like that didn't usually acknowledge his existence, let alone desired to sit next to him.

She sat down and looked Taylor up and down.

"You don't usually sit here... Taylor, right? I think we're in French together." she said. "I'm..."

"Sophia Marcus." Taylor finished. "You sit a few rows behind me."

"What brings you to this table, today? Your usual one full up?" she asked.

Taylor was amazed, Sophia was a cheerleader, and they usually steered clear of the greasy stoner kids, yet she's actually talking to him! Maybe the book was right...

"It was that assembly this morning... Lucy Wong got me thinking about a change of scenery." Taylor replied.

"Oh, she's awesome. It was so inspirational, I wish she'd done a meet and greet after, I'd have loved to chat with her." Sophia said.

"I ran into her in the hallway. She gave me this." Taylor dug the book out of his bag. Lucy Wong might be his ticket to getting a date.

"Her book! That's awesome! Can I see?"

"Sure, she even signed it."

"Dear Taylor, If you find yourself, you can never be lost. Best wishes, Lucy Wong!" Sophia read. "That's so cool!"

"I guess, I wasn't sure I bought into that stuff, but now I'm not sure." Taylor said.

"Are you reading it, cause I'd love to borrow it." Sophia said.

"Uh..." Taylor started.

On the one hand, lending the book to Sophia would really increase his chances with her, on the other hand, the book was working, and he'd barely gotten started, he needed its guidance. Decisions... decisions...
123111.title: Taylor decides to sit with the jocks

1231111.content:
"Yeah, sure." Taylor smiled as he handed the book to Sophia, who started to flip through it.

"I've got study hall next period, and I'm a fast reader, so I'll probably be done before the end of the day..." Sophia started.

"No rush." Taylor said.

"I've got an idea! I've got cheerleading after school. How about you come and watch us practice, and I'll give it back to you after." Sophia offered.

While Taylor had no interest in staying after school for anything... the idea of being welcomed to sit on the bleachers and watch the cheerleaders running around sounded very nice.

"Sure." Taylor smiled.

"Great!" Sophia grinned. "See you then."

Once lunch was over, Taylor went to his next class, excited about meeting up with Sophia, so much so that instead of his usual take-his-time approach he took to the halls, he eagerly rushed through the halls to the classroom, until being stopped by his friend Kevin, who pulled him aside.

"Hey man, where were you at lunch? Get collared for the lockers?" Kevin asked.

"You're not gonna believe this, but I spent lunch talking with Sophia Marcus." Taylor replied, grinning.

"No way, man!" Kevin exclaimed. "How'd you manage that?"

"That Lucy Wong lady gave me her book, and Sophia's totally into that junk, and she saw it and went crazy!" Taylor replied, leaving out the fact that the book had inspired him to seek out a new seating arrangement.

"Nice!" Kevin smiled. "You still on for after school? Bud's got some new kush he wants to try out at his place."

"I can't." Taylor said. "Sophia borrowed the book, and she wants to return it to me. After cheerleading. I'm gonna sit on the bleachers and wait."

Kevin nodded knowingly, and patted his friend on the shoulder.

"Good luck, man." Kevin said. "See you tomorrow?"

"Bet." Taylor said, but didn't entirely mean, because if Sophia wanted to hang around him... he'd drop everything for it.

Taylor spent the entire class anticipating the end of the day, but instead of anticipating getting out of school to hang with his friends, he was anticipating seeing how far this thing with Sophia could go.
1231111.title: Taylor lends the book to Sophia

choices: That night, Taylor reads the next chapter
12311111.content:
The rest of the day came and went, and soon, Taylor found himself walking onto the bleachers in the gym as the cheerleaders started their warm-ups. Taylor felt conspicuous, until Sophia spotted him, smiled and waved at him. It was a good feeling to be welcomed to watch. And it was an even better feeling to see the cheerleaders doing all their stretching, jumping and gymnastic feats.

Watching this beats hotboxing with the guys, any day.

"Actually..." Taylor thought to himself as he reached into his pocket, pulling out a small joint.

He started looking for his lighter, and for the quickest exit to the outside. He spotted one and quickly ducked away as the cheerleaders started assembling their tower.

After getting outside, he lit up the joint and took a big puff off of it.

And immediately regretted it. Taylor began hacking up a lung and gagging, rushing to a nearby garbage can.

"Oh god..." Taylor felt another retch coming on, but managed to hold it back.

Taylor steadied himself and calmed himself down, dropping the joint onto the floor and stepping on it, before picking it back up.

"What the hell happened?" Taylor wondered.

In-fact, he tried to remember where he'd gotten that joint or how long it had been sitting in that pocket. Clearly far too long if it tasted so disgusting. He'd never had any problems with pot before, heck, he'd lit up only that morning, and it was fine.

"Maybe I should take a break from this stuff." Taylor sighed as he tossed the joint into the garbage and returned to watch the cheerleaders.

Because he was looking to forget all about that wretched taste, Taylor found himself enraptured by the cheerleading practice. The gymnastics, the chants... not that he'd ever admit it to himself, but it looked... fun. Not that he'd actually want to try it, but if Sophia asked, he might give it a shot...

"Bet that was pretty boring." Sophia said, breaking Taylor from his reverie. She was out of her uniform, already? How long had Taylor been lost in thought?

"Oh yeah... it was cool though, all the flips and stuff." Taylor said.

"Want to give it a try?" she asked.

"I don't think my body is meant to bend that way." he replied.

"Wanna know a little secret? No one's is at first, it takes a lot of practice and a lot of stretching to get like that." Sophia giggled.

Taylor smiled in return.

"I finished it in study hall, such a good book, lots of great motivational stuff. I bet you'll love it." Sophia said.

"I hope so." Taylor said.

Sophia's phone chimed and she checked it.

"Oh shoot, I've gotta run, but I'll see you around, right?" Sophia said.

"Right." Taylor smiled.

Taylor basically floated home, he was friends with a cheerleader! Normally this would call for a celebration bong hit but... he wanted to take it easy.
12311111.title: After school

123111111.content:
Taylor got into his room and tossed his bag onto the floor, before hopping into bed. Usually, he would light up for a bit, but today, Taylor was content to just relax. He turned the book over in his hands and flipped through it, checking to see if he could see which section Sophia liked the most. Upon not finding much, he settled on just reading the next chapter.

Step 1 had seemed to work fairly well. Sure, Taylor didn't quite know his purpose or direction yet, but at least he was making new friends. As he read, he absentmindedly twirled his hair on his finger, like he'd seen Sophia do a few times in French class, not that he recognized that he was even performing the gesture.

"Chapter 2..." Taylor began to read aloud to himself. "Setting attainable goals is important for personal growth. They can be small, such as to do yoga once a week, or large, like losing weight. The important thing to remember is to make sure they are positive goals. If you want to change, you've got to put in the work for it."

Taylor began to think about his own goals... or rather his lack of them. He'd admitted as much to Lucy Wong that he didn't plan on going to college, but the more he thought about it, the less he liked the idea. Sure, college was expensive, and he'd probably have to take out loans, but that didn't mean it wasn't worth it. In fact, the jocks have direction because they're probably all getting scholarships.

"Maybe I should look into a scholarship..." Taylor mused.

Academics was never his strong suit, but he could try, or maybe there's an extra-curricular or sport he could get into. The only one coming to his mind at the moment was cheerleading, probably because he couldn't get Sophia out of his head, but he'd think of something.

Taylor suddenly realized that he'd zoned out for hours and it was getting late, so he started getting ready for bed.
123111111.title: That night, Taylor reads the next chapter

1231111111.content:
Taylor yawned as he woke up and brushed his hair out of his face as his alarm blared. He quickly turned it off and started his morning routine. Typically it included a shower, getting dressed, and if there was time, some goofing off on his phone before he had to hightail it off to school. With two working parents, Taylor had taken on all the onus for getting himself ready for school by the time he was in junior high, so this routine was long-ingrained into him.

Usually after a shower, Taylor simply brushed his hair out, sloppily dried it, and called it a day, but for some reason, that wasn't cutting it today.

"Is my hair... shinier?" Taylor questioned as he observed a strand in the mirror. "Then again, it's been a few days since I washed it, maybe I just didn't get all the oil out."

Taylor tried several ways of styling it, brushing it both over and behind his ears, but nothing seemed to satisfy him.

"Whatever..." Taylor gave up and returned to his bedroom, grabbing the Lucy Wong book off his nightstand and as he picked it up, something small fell out of it.

Taylor knelt over to pick it up.

"A... hair tie?" Taylor examined the object in his hand. It was a baby-blue hair tie. "How did..."

Taylor wondered how the hair tie got into his book, until he remembered who he lent it to.

"Sophia's, probably. Must've gotten stuck in there when it was in her bag. But I wonder why I didn't find it last night while reading..." Taylor ignored that question, because he had just gotten an idea.

He rushed back to the mirror and pulled his hair into the hair tie. He'd never been one to tie his hair back, but maybe, just maybe, this style would satisfy him. Taylor was unskilled with the hair tie, so in his attempt to make a low ponytail, he ended up slightly higher, but that was for the best, since Taylor was finally happy with his hair.

"Perfect!" Taylor smiled. "Let's just hope Sophia doesn't ask for it back."

Taylor gathered his things and headed off to school. As he grabbed some things from his locker,

"Hey, Taylor!" a voice called out.

Taylor shut his locker to find a familiar person standing next to it. Who is it?
1231111111.title: The next morning

123112.content: Let's be specific. What kind of geeks?
123112.title: Be more specific

choices: English as a Second Language courses
1231122.content:
Taylor scanned the lunchroom, sizing up his options. Who would be the best group of people to emulate?

Several members of the debate team were seated along the wall. They were pretty smart, and certainly confident and well-spoken. Most already knew where they headed after graduation. Maybe if Taylor got in their good graces, he could piggyback off their success.

The team were hunched over notebooks, binders and index cards, researching and preparing their various arguments. None of them saw Taylor approach.

"Hi," he said to the studious bunch. "Do you care if I sit here?"

"Yeah, sure," said one of the kids, reading a hardcover book. It looked complicated and boring. Certainly, nothing Taylor would dare try reading. "Just don't spill anything, okay? The last thing I need is more food stains on my notes."

"I said I was sorry, Jake," one of the girls said.

"Well, you should have been using your head. You didn't think spaghetti sauce was going to spatter everywhere? Come on, Iris. You eat like a four year-old," he shot back.

Iris stuck out her tongue at Jake in defiance. She returned to her notes, highlighting key passages.

"You all seem pretty testy," Taylor said.

"We're in big trouble," Iris said. "We have a meet this weekend, and one of our co-captains is in the hospital with appendicitis. We're all struggling to piece together his argument from his leftover notes."

"Anything I can do to help?" Taylor asked.

"Yeah," Jake said, "I mean, if you want to. We need someone to debate the merits of..."
1231122.title: Debate team

12311221.content:
"...school uniforms," Jake said.

"Oh, that's easy," Taylor said. "Uniforms suck."

"Yeah, okay, maybe," Iris said, "but that's not how it works. You won't know whether you're arguing for or against the topic until the debate begins. You need to be prepared to defend either side of the argument. Come up with every possible topic, and be ready to counter it or support it."

"That's a lot of work," Taylor said. He was halfway hoping Jake and Iris and the rest would let him renege on his promise, and he could go back to playing video games in the back corner of the library, back where the librarian couldn't see him.

But the beaming face of Lucy Wong smiled up at him from his book. Taylor wanted to be a better person, and he wasn't going to do so by being lazy and breaking promises.

"Okay, I'll do it," Taylor said. Jake handed him the notes of his hospitalized teammate, and Taylor began looking up articles on his phone to help research the subject.

Strange though, his normally blue cell phone case looked remarkably lighter today. Almost baby blue.

Taylor ascribed the oddity to lighting, and went back to reading, beginning with the history of school uniforms. As he read, he itched his legs with the toe of his shoes. His leg hairs bristled as his socks began slowly growing, climbing up his legs. The normally ankle-length socks snaked upwards, stopping just shy of his knees.
12311221.title: Mandatory school uniforms

123112211.content:
Taylor knew he was in over his head, but his tasks weren't impossible. He needed to keep his mind sharp and his attention focused. He needed to get some food in his stomach. That would help him concentrate.

Taylor got up from the table and headed to the cafeteria line. Normally, he would chow down on a cheeseburger, a slice of pepperoni pizza, or a plate of tacos, each served with a mound of french fries. Along with, he would chug down a bottle of Dr Pepper. Today, none of his usual fare seemed appetizing. Everything seemed greasy and nauseating. He was still hungry, but he
wanted something that wouldn't sit in his stomach like a rock.

Perusing his remaining options, he selected a turkey sandwich with lettuce and tomatoes. He opted for a bottle of water along with it. As he grabbed his wallet from his pockets, he noticed his shorts looking substantially more blue than before. What's more, they seemed to be creased now. How oddly was he sitting to crease them like that, he wondered? Taylor had never needed to know the term 'pleated' before, which is why he didn't recognize the style.

Paying the lunch lady, Taylor attempted to return his wallet to his pockets, but noticed it no longer fit. Was it somehow larger than before, or had his pockets shrunk? Both, actually, not that he had any idea how such a thing could happen. As he sheepishly tried to shove his oversized wallet back into a pocket that was gradually being sewn up, he realized he was holding up the lunch line. He took his sandwich and water, heading back to his seat, wallet in hand.

Looking down at his questionable billfold, he noticed it looked not just larger, but bulging. Distended. As though it were ballooning, capable of holding much more than just paper money. The curiosity of the situation took all of Taylor's attention, making him completely oblivious to his leg hairs disappearing completely.
123112211.title: Taylor gets some lunch

1231122111.content:
With nothing else to do with it his wallet, Taylor set it on top of the table. He took a small bite of his sandwich, opened one of the books, and began skimming the various arguments in favor of school uniforms. Surprisingly, his eyes were moving faster than he was accustomed to. The words were sinking in. He was blitzing through page after page, and what's more, retaining the actual subjects. He hadn't read this easily since books stopped being about cats in hats.

Taylor took a few drinks of his water, trying to cool himself down. The room had suddenly gotten much warmer. Was he sitting under an air duct? He started fidgeting with the collar of his shirt, trying to cool down.

Taylor's sleeves had grown down his arms, all the way to his wrists. Before they could envelope his hands, they folded back on themselves, becoming a pair of dress cuffs. The soft cotton fabric of his tee became starched, bleaching from the black it once was to a pure white. The skate punk logo on the front split in two as the shirt was cut from his neck to his waist, being clasped closed by buttons.

Like a rising loaf of bread, the fabric along Taylor's back, shoulders, and chest began to swell. It expanded, leaving his newly formed sleeves and starched collar alone. As the fabric swelled, the outside facing Iris, Jake and the others turned thicker and softer. The inside, still grazing Taylor's softening, hairless skin was cotton. The outside was wool, darkening, turning the same royal blue as his pleated shorts. With a small shoulder roll, the two garments separated, leaving Taylor with a crisp white blouse and a blue sweater vest.

"Everything okay, Taylor?" Jake asked.

Taylor stopped and thought. Wasn't he hot just a moment ago? He guessed not. Perhaps it was just the stress getting to him.

"Peachy," Taylor said, perplexed by his odd choice of words. He finished his bottle of water and stood from the table. "Excuse me, I need to use the, um, facilities." Taylor tried to say he was going to take a piss, but his tongue betrayed him. Why had it come out so eloquent?

"I'll go with you," Iris said.

Taylor stood confused for a moment by the offer, but Iris paid him no mind. She walked off to the bathroom. Taylor, not wanting to betray his bladder, followed.

After two steps, he doubled back to the table to grab his wallet. His confusion was so vast, he didn't even notice the leather strap now hanging from it.
1231122111.title: Is it too late in the year for a sweater vest?

choices: Those shoes do not go with that outfit
12311221111.content:
'Something strange is going on,' Taylor thought silently. 'Why do I feel so... icky? And gosh darn it, why am I talking so strange?'

Taylor arrived at the restrooms, and almost blindly followed Iris into the girl's room, but stopped before crossing the threshold. Something may be bothering him, but he still had to keep his wits about. He backed up and proceeded into the boy's room.

The room was empty, except for Taylor. He stepped up the urinals, but they all seemed to be out of order. Probably vandalism, or a plumbing issue. Shrugging off the inconvenience, Taylor entered one of the stalls.

Taylor tried to lift the seat, but found it stuck firm. No matter how hard he pulled, he couldn't move it more than a few inches. More than that, whenever he let go, it fell back down to its resting position. Taylor hung his engorged wallet on the provided hook in the stall. He braced one of his feet atop the toilet paper dispenser and tried one more pull with all his might. He strained and groaned, until he heard a rip.

He couldn't tell from his vantage point, but Taylor ripped the crotch of his shorts. He felt between his legs, and sure enough, he could feel his underpants. Taylor sized up his options. There wasn't enough time in his lunch period to run down to the locker room and change into his gym shorts. He could probably find some replacement pants in the lost and found, but what are the odds anything would fit him? Taylor just resolved to take small steps. Nobody would notice if he took small steps.

Defeated, Taylor reluctantly sat down on the toilet to relieve himself. Examining his shorts further, the hole was much larger than he initially worried. He didn't recall where he purchased them, but they must have been very cheap. Taylor couldn't even discern where one leg started and the other began. It was almost like his shorts were one giant pant leg.

Taylor thought he felt some water splash up on him. He delicately patted himself dry before standing up and flushing. He pulled up his underwear, which felt thinner than he remembered. It also sat much higher on his hips than he was used to. He fastened his shorts, and sure enough, he could feel his thighs rubbing against one another. He reminded himself to take small, calculated steps, almost like he was walking a tightrope. One foot in front of the other, lest anyone notice he ripped the crotch of his shorts into oblivion.

Grabbing his wallet from the hook, he couldn't help but notice just how large it had become. How strange an ordinary everyday object could go so un-examined. He had never noticed how big his wallet was. Or how the purple leather looked in this light. Or how the brass zipper... wait, since when do wallets have zippers?

"Are you okay in there, Taylor?" came a voice from beyond the stall doors.

"Just fine," he lied. Taylor grabbed his belongings and unlocked the stall door. There, he was greeted face to face with Iris. "What are you doing here?" he asked in a panic.

"Well, I heard you flush, then you were just kind of standing around in there," Iris replied. "I didn't know if you needed a pad or something."

Taylor was shocked. He meant to ask why Iris was in the boy's room, not outside his stall. And what would he need a pad for? Why would he be taking notes?

Taylor looked around. The urinals were gone. There was no evidence they were ever there. Just more bathroom stalls. Iris wasn't in the boy's room, Taylor was in the girl's room! How could he have possibly made such a mistake? He was so careful. How gracious of Iris not to freak out about this. Taylor simply slumped his head in embarrassment and moved towards the exit.

"Wait, don't go," Iris said. "I need you to hold my purse while I... you know."

Taylor fidgeted in anxious nerves, ready to dart for the door at the first moment. "Can't you just put it on the hook?" he asked, looking for his escape.

"No, I'm always paranoid someone's going to come by and reach over the door and grab it. Please, please, please, I'll just be a minute."

Taylor relented. "Okay, just be quick." Iris smiled and handed Taylor her bag, excusing herself to a stall. Taylor examined Iris's purse. Then he looked at his wallet. Then her purse again. Then his wallet again. There was something odd about the two of them. Something almost familiar.

It was giving him a headache to think about. Taylor put both bags down on the shelf by the sink. He turned on the faucet and lathered up with soap. He couldn't help but notice just how clean and trim his nails were. And shiny too. As though they were polished.

'Get a grip,' Taylor thought to himself. 'You'll be fine. Nothing else bad is going to happen to you.'

Taylor stopped mid-thought. Out of the corner of his eye, he saw someone standing in the doorway. Anybody seeing him in the girl's room would be bad enough, but this was Carrie Applegate. Carrie was one of the cruelest mean girls to attend his school. In five minutes, Carrie would be texting the entire student body that Taylor was some sort of creepy pervert who spied on girls on toilet. At least, that's what Taylor feared.

Instead, Carrie just looked Taylor up and down and said:
12311221111.title: Taylor uses the men's room

choices: “Meet up with us after school for studying and practice”
“Hold onto the notes and keep looking at them”
123112211112.content:
“Your face is gross,” Carrie sneered. “If you hate makeup you could at least wash.”

“Hey, I wash,” Taylor responded, not registering the bit about makeup.

“Well clearly you’re not doing it enough,” Carrie said dismissively, walking past and entering a stall herself.

Taylor looked over, annoyed, but Iris emerged from the stall at this point. “Ignore her,” she said as she started washing her hands. “She just likes insulting people. You look fine.” Taylor glanced at his reflection. It looked...slightly different than he was used to. A bit lighter, a bit smoother. And his hair looked a bit longer than it was this morning.

It was confusing to think about, and the thought disappeared as Iris spoke up. “Thanks for holding my purse,” she said.

“Uh, you’re welcome,” Taylor replied, handing it over. As the two left the bathroom, Taylor snuck a glance at the sign on the door. Obviously, it was the girls’ room. But why hadn’t Iris or Carrie said anything? They had both acted like it was normal for him to be in there. Taylor followed Iris as the two walked back to the lunch table. Nobody seemed to notice the tear in Taylor’s shorts, nor the way he was walking in an attempt to hide it.

Iris and Taylor returned to their seats, Taylor placing his now-much-larger wallet on the table again, next to the debate books. He, and the rest of the team, finished off their lunch while continuing to study. Soon, it was the end of lunch period and time for the next class.

“What would you like me to do, everyone?” Taylor asked, still speaking more politely than he expected.
123112211112.title: Return to lunch

choices: Wait, I'm not done with Taylor yet
1231122111121.content:
Taylor studied throughout the remainder of the lunch period. Somehow, he had gone through the entire notebook. He not only had a full grasp of the arguments, he felt as though he had written them himself.

The bell rang. Jake and Iris collected their things and prepared to depart. "I guess we'll see you after school," Jake said. "We'll go through a trial run to make sure you're ready."

"Oh wait," Taylor said, "I'll walk with you."

"Thanks, hon," Iris said, "But don't you have to go?"

"What do you mean?" Taylor asked confused. "I'm going to sixth period, just like you."

"Yeah, that's why you need to get going," Jake said.

Taylor was confused. Maybe he ran in different circles than these debaters, but they didn't have to shun him like this.

"Excuse me," Taylor said, crossing his arms. The motion felt weird. Like something was getting in the way of arms. "What are you implying?"

"Come on, Tay-Tay," Jake said playfully. "Isn't The Redding Academy like a fifteen minute drive? I mean, aren't they sticklers for rules and such? Show up tardy and they smack your wrists with a ruler?"

Taylor rolled his eyes. The Redding Academy was a prestigious institute of learning, not some stereotypical Catholic girl's school. The teachers weren't nuns. There was no corporal punishment. And sure, maybe there was an emphasis on decorum and punctuality--- Taylor stopped his train of thought. How did he know all of this?

He looked down at himself. His hair was now shoulder length, and draped over a crisp white blouse. His navy blue sweater vest matched his pleated knee-length skirt. An inch of skin showed beneath the flared hemline before his legs were covered in ivory white knee socks. Emblazoned over his left breast was the Redding Academy logo, and yes, he indeed had breasts now. He could feel their weight in his bra. Taylor pursed his lips in fear. He could taste lip gloss.

Of course Taylor didn't go to this school anymore, he reasoned. Students at this school didn't wear uniforms. He was wearing a uniform. He went to another school. He went to Redding Academy. Taylor whipped open his purse. There, among the cosmetics, was his school ID. Redding Academy. Name: Taylor Kirtchner. Sex: F.

Taylor knew all this, but still knew enough that this was all wrong. He grabbed his purse and his notes and took off running. As he bounded down the hallways with each step, his shoes lost their laces. The black Nikes he had been wearing became thinner, smaller, and grew a slight heel. When he was just 500 feet short of the school's front door, they had become a pair of patent leather loafers with a one inch heel.

He stopped as he approached the glass front door. There, parked outside was a school bus reading "Redding Academy" on the side. A formal, but polite looking woman looked at him. "Miss Kirtchner, there you are. Please, get on the bus."

"No, please," Taylor began to mewl. "I can't go... I can't... I'm not..."

"You're late enough as is. Get on the bus with the rest of the girls, now!"

A hand rested gently on the small of Taylor's back. "I'm so sorry," Lucy said. "Taylor and I met up after the assembly. She had some questions, and I was trying to assist her as best I could."

"Is that so?" the teacher asked.

"Yes," Lucy said. "Taylor took issue with my self-help seminar. She felt the power of positive thinking was nice, but lacked any sort of applicability for herself. She's been quite a bit concerned about college and the ensuing debt. While the Redding Academy is quite nice in terms of academics, it's rather lacking in extracurricular activities. So, I pulled a few strings, and now Taylor will be representing this school in the district's debate tournament. The prize is quite a sizable scholarship. And as it turns out, many past recipients have gone on to receive internships in government and major corporations."

"Is that so? Well, congratulations Taylor. It looks like you're on the fast track to success now."

"Now, now," Lucy said. "She was always on the right track. She just needed to see the opportunities available a little more clearly. That's what thinking positive can achieve."

Taylor saw flashes of her future. College life. Academic awards. Career opportunities. It made her little knees tremble. Maybe... Maybe this wouldn't be so bad?

"Oh by the way, Taylor," Lucy said. "Before you go, you left this behind." Lucy handed Taylor her book once again. Seven Steps to a More Highly Effective You!

Lucy had even autographed it. "To Taylor, So glad I could Bolster your Spirits. - Lucy Wong."
1231122111121.title: See you after school

12311221111211.content:
The rest of the school day passed uneventfully. Muscle memory and instinct guided Taylor through her classes and around the halls of Redding Academy. Familiar faces greeted her, even though she knew with certainty she had never met them before. She slipped into this life and routine seamlessly. It was made for her, after all.

Her new classes were challenging, but engaging. Her new classmates weren't any more stuck-up or elitist than other teenagers her age. And her new body was so comfortable and familiar, she began to forget it wasn't the same body she had this morning.

When she arrived home, she found her family unchanged except for their memories. They had no idea Taylor ever was a boy. She had simply always been as she is. The photographs hanging in the hallway reflected this is how it always had been.

Taylor's bedroom was the biggest change of all. Not outlandishly girly, it simply looked neat and tidy. The bedroom of a fastidious individual who appreciated things orderly and clean. Taylor took his transformation into a teenage girl in stride. Turning into a preppy, goody two shoes was the big adjustment.

Taylor laid out a new outfit to replace her school uniform. A pink polo to replace the sweater vest and blouse. A pair of high-waisted khakis to take the place of her skirt. A simple pair of ballet flats on her feet and a strand of pearls to complete the classy, casual look. Taylor hung her uniform on a hanger, returning it to the closet for tomorrow. And the day after. And for the rest of the year. And every year until she graduated, summa cum laude, of course.

Taylor considered calling her old friends, checking in on them, seeing if they even remembered who he or she was, but decided against it. The more time passed, the more her old life seemed like a dull movie she once watched. She then considered calling her new friends, but was similarly disinclined. If she didn't start her homework now, she wouldn't have time to finish her chores before dinner. And if she didn't finish her chores, there wouldn't be time before sunset to go running in the park. And after all that, she still needed to prep for the debate tournament before going to bed at 9:00 sharp.

Taylor sighed as she fastened the clasp of pearls around her neck. Taylor knew a day this busy was the new normal. This was her life. Nothing good ever came easy. And Taylor was a very good girl.
12311221111211.title: Epilogue - Taylor's new life

124.content: A College? or maybe a Technical School

choices: A Lonely quiet kid, just coasting through life
1241.content:
Lucy had just finished a talk at a Big University and was outside the auditorium meeting with a few of the Audience, during the show she'd been on the lookout for any audience members in desperate need of her program and had spotted a few needy customers.

As the audience filed out, she made sure to stop one person in particular
1241.title: College

choices: the Girls of Gamma Alpha Lamba seek out Milo
12411.content:
Lucy eyed the Kid, most likely a Freshman... and, she had a pretty good eye for things like this... seemed like he wasn't that outgoing... and hoped college would be a big change for him, except it hadn't been, but Lucy could help.

She tailed him and ended up at a Coffee shop, she maneuvered her way to the table next to him, and made sure she was noticed.

Before long the kid looked up and seemed surprised.

"Are you Lucy Wong... I was just at your talk, it was incredible."

"I am! You were? Oh thank you, that's so sweet." She exchanged pleasantries and made small talk and waited... she just had a way with people, they would tell her their problems, and within a few minutes the boy... Milo was doing just that.

"It's just... I don't know how to make friends, I want to socialize but have no reason to go out and don't know anyone, I feel like I'm wasting my college years."

Lucy smiled "Well I've got a few connections, I'm a Legacy of one of the Sororities here and I'm sure there's good people there."

"Oh I don't know... I barely know anyone, and..." he paused.

Blushing, he nodded his head..

Girl's aren't just skirts and makeup, plenty of them like comic books, movies, games adventures, let me give your name to a few friends and see what I can do"

"I don't know..."

"I... I guess, thank you."

Lucy Smiled.
12411.title: A Lonely quiet kid, just coasting through life

choices: The man literally bumps into her
13.content:
The North County career fair was a bustling with people looking for opportunity, employment, and advancement. Businesses from all over the state were in attendance, looking for the best and brightest, the hard-working, and the diamonds in the rough.

Lucy Wong was preparing her notes as keynote speaker for the event. Her Gain-A-Life program often inspired people to abandon their dead-end jobs; seeking their dreams, or at least greener pastures. Career fairs were a great opportunity to network, sell her program, and research her next book.

Lucy went over the speech in her mid as she checked her appearance in the bathroom mirror. Her make-up was exquisite. Her skin was immaculate. Her hair was shiny, with nary a follicle out of place. Her outfit was clean, perfectly tailored, and pressed.

As she left the restroom, heading towards the event's podium, she ran into a strange man. What happened?
13.title: A career fair

133.content:
As Lucy left the bathroom, there was a man standing nearby. A man of relatively young age, probably no more than late 20's at the absolutely maximum. The man was dressed similarly to many of the other people around, a nice suit and tie and everything that goes with it. Fairly standard stuff.

"Can I help you?" Lucy asked calmly, having had encounters with many people before.

"Oh, s-sorry," the man said. "Got a little nervous is all. I'm David Thomas, ma'am."

David was a pretty sincere man, and many would describe him as someone with a good heart. However, things weren't exactly the best with his situation. He had a college degree, but it went absolutely nowhere, still being stuck on minimum wage to this day. He had gone to numerous job fairs like this one, hoping to find at least someone to give him a chance. Appearance-wise, he had a rather average build, not exactly the most exercised, but still relatively thin. He had short red-blonde hair with blue eyes too.

Oh, and the primary reason he happened to be standing where he was?

"Uh...I just wanted...to ask for an autograph, ma'am," he asked. "I saw your last special on TV last week and I thought it was pretty cool."

Ah, that had to be when she did her program in the next town over. Been a little while since she had seen someone approach her for an autograph, but she was happy to do so all the same. Heck, the kids loved it the last time she showed up at a daycare.

"Why thank you, young man," Lucy smiled, proceeding to do just what he asked. "And what is your name?"

"David...David Thomas," he smiled a bit.

"Pleasure to meet you," she said, handing his notebook back. "And if I may ask, what are you looking for here?"

So, once David was assured he wasn't holding her up, he recounted most of what had already happened with him. All the school and job stuff he struggled with.

"Mainly I just....want to get a chance somewhere. I can move out and not be a burden on my parents," he sighed a bit before looking back at Lucy. "Oh sorry...I kind of rambled there."

"No, it's alright," Lucy nodded, looking contemplative. "There are plenty of young men like you looking to make such a mark."

David could only imagine what would happen from here.
133.title: The man wants an autograph

1332.content:
David looked down at the autograph in his book. "To David, Always be ready to make your mark. - Lucy Wong"

A nice gesture, but an empty platitude. David shrugged off the dismissal. Lucy was a millionaire and an icon. Of course she wouldn't bother with a lowly little nobody like him.

"Thank you," he said all the same. He offered Lucy her pen back.

"Oh no, you keep it. Consider it a gift."
David looked confused at the gesture. This wasn't an ordinary plastic ballpoint pen. This was a quality writing instrument; thirty dollars at least. It looked to be part of a set. It was even inscribed.

He tried to refuse, but when he looked up again, Lucy was gone.

David looked down at the inscription on the pen. "Cooper, Kauffman, and Associates" the writing said. David had never heard of such an organization. But if Lucy knew them, they must be worth investigating.

David opened his book once again to admire the writing. "To D," it read. "Always be ready to make your mark. - Lucy Wong"

David tucked a lock of his strawberry blonde hair behind his ear, and set out to find the mysterious company.



What happens next?
1332.title: It's just a pen, isn't it?

choices: Leave it there. Whoever left it will be coming back for it.
13322.content:
David hustled along the floor of the career fair, looking for any indication of Cooper, Kauffman, and Associates. He didn't even know what kind of company they were. A law firm? Marketing? Sales? The pen was his only lead.

Perhaps there was a directory or map of the attendees somewhere? Most likely by the front door, David reasoned. As he navigated the labyrinthine convention center, he couldn't help but stop as his toes started hurting. He felt his feet rubbing up against the inside of his shoes. His toes were being rubbed raw, as though he weren't wearing any socks.

David sat down on a bench, and undid the laces of his shoe so he could rub his aching toes. The black socks he was wearing looked strange to him. The material was much thinner than he last remembered. What's more, instead of the crew-length cut he preferred, his socks reached up halfway to his knees. One final confusing point, David only remembered ever buying black dress socks. These were looking brown, almost tan.

He put his shoes back on, shaking off the peculiarity. It must have been a packaging error, or something. His feet were feeling better already. Although, had he been more observant, he would have realized it was not the footrub that did so. The laces and tongues of his shoes were wisped away, leaving him in a pair of what appeared to be a pair of ballet flats


As David collected his things, he foundd a red handbag sitting on the bench beside him. David didn't see the purse when he sat down, but there it was now.


What does he do with the purse?
13322.title: David's feet start hurting

133223.content:
David looked into the purse to see if there was an ID that would tell him who’s purse this belonged to. Going inside the bag he found a typical assortment of female products, makeup, lipstick, gum, etc. finally he found a really nice black leather wallet as he opened it and looked for the ID.

There inside the wallet was a driver’s license as David began to get a little confused. The name on the ID was for one

“Danielle Thomas, Age 27, 5’7 120lbs.” It was even labeled as an organ donor with blood type A- the same as David’s.

The woman in the photo was rather stunning. A gorgeous blonde with bright green eyes that looked strangely similar to his own...

David began to get a little worried about all these strange coincidences. The woman this ID belonged too seemed almost like his female doppelgänger.

David knew he probably shouldn’t keep snooping around but at this point his curiosity got the better of him. He looked into the purse more as he found a couple photographs tucked away inside it.

The photos were of a recent vacation this Danielle seemed to have taken. She was standing on a beach wearing a bright blue bikini and David had to admit she looked stunning. She had large breasts easily DD cups or maybe a bit bigger. She had great curves and a perfect bubble butt and her long flowing blonde hair came down past her waist.

The photos had her posing on the beach and strangely in one of the photos she was kissing a guy...a...boyfriend maybe. David couldn’t make out who the guy was very clearly but he could swear it looked just like his best friend Travis.

The final strange thing David found was a business card in the purse which had her name on it. Apparently she was a receptionist at a rather prestigious law firm...CKA. Or Cooper, Kauffman, and Associates.

This was all too much for David. He put everything back where he found it and got up and decided to leave this career fair and just go home. David rushed out of the auditorium and to his car breathing heavily as he almost ran out of there.

David hadn’t even noticed yet his socks had continued their changes this whole time turning into a very fine pair of pantyhose as the fronts of his shoes were melting away as a small heel was developing on them.

David spun out of the parking lot driving the car like he stole it taking in a deep sigh of relief not even bothering to check his back seat as a very familiar looking purse was sitting there...
133223.title: Check for ID

1332231.content:
"Sigh...well that sucked," David groaned as he drove along, slowing down his driving a bit as he began to calm down.

Well, that was another job fair down the drain, though easily the weirdest one to boot with that whole purse business. And to think he thought things might turn around with getting a chance to see Lucy Wong in person, though come to think of it, he never even stayed around to hear her speech given how fast he ran out. He looked over to his cupholder, where he had inserted that pen. It still looked the same, having the same words as before. Honestly, he wasn't sure what to think of his meeting with her now.

"Well, nothing to it then," he sighed again as he made a left turn.

Guess he might as well head back to his apartment, back to his own place of privacy. He had just enough money to live on his own in an apartment, even if it wasn't by much. Still, it could be worse all things considered.

Eventually, he came up to a red light, making a stop there. Granted, it was a section notorious for taking a while so he would be waiting a bit.

"Great..." he groaned, knowing this would take a while.

As he sat there though, something felt a little off. His head felt...itchy all of a sudden. Perhaps because of all the agitation he had just felt over the past few minutes or so. He reached a hand up to scratch it, just to get his mind off of it. However, once he was doing that, the hair he was feeling felt....different?

"Huh?" he spoke as he looked up to the mirror to get a better view. Honestly, he wished he hadn't soon after.

Right where his hand was was some noticeably longer hair. Considering he just had a hair cut the week before, the difference was staggering was it getting long enough to cover his ears. Actually, if you looked closely, you could even see it slowly growing longer right before his eyes!

"What the hell?!" he cried out loud.

Further more, some strands of his hair were starting to look considerably blonder, the little bit of red he had slowly fading out in certain places. The roots especially were looking much brighter, starting to trail off into the longer strands. A slight shiver went down his body as it felt it begin to touch his neck, hair flowing a little more loosely now.

"Oh no....this must be a dream...." he muttered to himself, eyes wide and nearly in a panic. "It's not real....It's not real...."

At that moment, the light finally went green, and he began going before someone could honk him. However, as he put his foot on the gas, he felt a little ache, making him grunt a bit. Sparing a look further down, he was greeted with another surprise. He could see his toes! They were clad in...something tan? Certainly not the dress socks he had before. Also, his shoes seemed much smaller and conforming to his feet, even lacking laces and a tongue.

And even more so, they were cracking and reshaping as a little heel was growing even longer.
1332231.title: More changes in the car

13322311.content:
David was on the verge of having a panic attack so to calm down he sped into a nearby gas station to get a look at what was happening to him. He needed to see this with his own eyes.

As he got out of the car he ran up to the door and surprisingly a random guy opened the door for him. What was weirder was the guy gave David a rather creepy smile and a small wink like he was checking him out...

Not stopping to dwell on it David rushed to the bathroom and confirmed his worst fears. His hair was much longer now and was still getting brighter in color.

“Oh my god...” He said in shock and disbelief as he held the handfuls of hair in his hands. It was long enough to touch his shoulders now.

Dave couldn’t stand for this. He stormed out of the bathroom and went into one of the aisles and found a pair of scissors and marched back into the bathroom and began cutting away. Lock after lock of hair he cut and cut going as short as possible. After a few minutes David stood there panting looking like he just lost a fight with a lawn mower....He looked like a total mess but it was worth it.

However not even a minute passed after he had finished cutting his hair when his scalp began to burn and itch. He began to itch and scratch his head as he saw in the mirror new hairs growing from his scalp these ones much more blonde than before. They grew and grew and grew and grew inches in a matter of seconds this time even longer before as in a matter of minutes he now had beautiful head of golden blonde hair that came passed his shoulders down to his kid back....

David couldn’t believe this! It had to be a curse or something! Grabbing the scissors once more he went to town again on his new lock shredding them down as short as humanly possible. By the time he was done this time his head looked almost bald...

“Good....now stay there...” David said in defiance looking at his mess of a head.

However his request was denied....and in such spectacular fashion it even left David speechless...

The itching returned but rather than a slowly growth the remaining hairs on his head actually began to fall out....The bright blonde locks simply fell off his head...Every last hair on his head disappearing right before his eyes as he was soon as bald and smooth as a china doll.

“Well...that’s better than the alternative...” David said rubbing his smooth head.

However this too was not meant to be...David soon felt the itching returned as new hairs were sprouting on his head. This time they were much brighter and longer than before...However unlike before these hairs weren’t just blonde they were a bright platinum blonde. Natural to roots as they were growing rapidly....Longer and longer they grew like pure silvery platinum silk the hair cascaded down his shoulders and back not resting until it was down past his waist...

It was like the hair of a model, perfectly silky and well maintained. Something that most women would kill for. It hung there perfectly off his head mocking him as if to teach him a lesson to stop trying to cut it...

David stood there shocked and defeated as he dropped the scissors. Any further attempts to stop this would only make it worse...

He had no idea what to do next when all of a sudden two random women walked into the bathroom and saw David. It was then David released he was actually in the ladies room. He stood there trying to think of an excuse but both of the women just stared and him and smiled.

“I like your hair.” One of them said.

“I know...How do you get it so straight and silky like that? What products do you use?” The other said.

Neither woman seemed disturbed at him being there as David didn’t respond and just left there awkwardly getting back into his car and driving off.
13322311.title: Making a stop

133223111.content:
Suffice to say, this was completely cuts. David took a little time to breathe before getting the car running again, thankfully not as fast this time so he wasn't swerving around cars.

"What is going on?!" he asked in frustration to just about no one. "It's like something out of a nightmare."

How in the world was this happening to him? Like some weird magic? That shouldn't even be a thing right? Well, unless he was hallucinating, it was very much real, and it seemed like it was trying to remind him of that. His long platinum blonde hair constantly tickled his shoulders, and he could feel it down his back the whole time. It was kind of annoying.

In any case, he didn't want to risk any more stops like that, lest he get noticed by anyone. It was particularly unnerving how those women just asked him questions like that as if everything was perfectly normal. That was spooky in and of itself. He didn't want to have to deal with any more of those. Thankfully his apartment wasn't too far away.

Come to think of it....he had basically gone all the way to the bathroom in the heels his shoes were turning into. How did that work?

"Ugh, hurts just thinking on it," he groaned.

However, as he was humming along on the freeway, another strange sensation seemed to be hitting him, making him groan again though he wasn't sure where it was coming from specifically this time. Though, as the sensation continued, he began to feel a tickling in his hands.

"Oh no..." he sighed, eyes widening a bit as he looked towards his hands on the wheel.

There was this strange cracking feeling, as if his hands were being compressed in to something a little smaller. Slowly but surely, his hands seemed to be getting smaller, while his fingers themselves seemed to be getting longer by comparison. However, that wasn't the big thing as something else that caught his eye. His fingernails seemed to be growing, made very obvious given he had cut them the other day.

And it wasn't just a little bit either, they were growing well past his fingertips, into a style that was very well maintained, even a little glossy too.

David had very little to actually say on it. What else could he say on something that seemed very supernatural? Frankly, he just wanted to get off the road before he panicked any more. Thankfully for him, his apartment was just around the corner, allowing him a chance to finally take a breather instead of worrying if his anxiety would make him crash.

And so, he parked into his usual spot, not sparing a thought as he began to go up the stairs towards his space a few floors up. He wasn't sure if it was the adrenaline or something, but he somehow did it while in those heels.
133223111.title: More changes while driving

choices: David notices more changes to himself
David sees changes around his apartment
1332231111.content:
David went into his apartment and shut himself inside locking the doors like he was terrified of something.

It took only a second for David to pull off his clothes and shoes as he looked at the now very feminine pair of high heels he had been wearing. What bothered him even more than the shoes however was the fact that they hadn’t even bothered him. He had actually walked in them rather comfortably...

David tried to pause and think. His mind was racing a million miles an hour. Was this magic? A curse? Was he dreaming or hallucinating? Why was he changing and why did nobody even seem to notice?

As David paced around his apartment in only his boxers he suddenly heard a strange ringing noise. It was the sound of a phone ringing but not his own...It was a more feminine ringing noise coming from the kitchen.

Following the sound David’s eyes widened as he saw the same red purse from before sitting on his kitchen counter...The same purse that started this whole thing...

The ringing was coming from there as David looked inside and saw a pink smartphone inside ringing as he picked it up. The name on the phone ringing said Eric Marshall....

Eric Marshall was David’s best friend. They had known each other since middle school. Why was he calling this phone? What relationship did he have with this Danielle woman?

David our of shear curiosity answered the phone as he heard on the other end.

“Hey baby, sorry to bug you I’m at work. I just wanted to let you know dinner reservations are for tomorrow at 7 at Sorintinos. I gotta go by, love you!” He said before hanging up.

David was confused. That was definitely Eric’s voice on the other end. He knew the restaurant, Sorintinos was a super fancy and expensive Italian restaurant that was usually far to expensive for him.

“What is going on here?” David asked more confused than ever.
1332231111.title: A bizarre call
